threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

depends largely on the stove design and what exact fuel you use like heet vs hardware store alcohol etc. also things like the altitude, weather, etc affect it especially if you're using a higher pressure alcohol stove design.
instead of giving you a generic answer that's probably wrong i'm going to tell you to boil a liter of water with a known volume of fuel in various weather conditions & time it to find out.
usually in alcohol stoves 1oz of generic fuel will get you boiling somewhere between 1-2 liters of water.
and rule of thumb: canister stove + fuel is lighter on longer trips, alcohol on shorter trips.

>>2502341
>I live near a decent sized lake but it's heavily used by weekender boat bros. Would one of these handle the chop from speed boats passing close by?
His Oldtown is one inch wider and one foot longer than my YuPIK (though it's also more tapered), and about 10 lbs. heavier, minus the pedaling shit.

Mine is extremely stable and handles chop very well (that's why my buddy bought one too), and is easy to stand up in with no assistance, though that's partly because it has a flat bottom with no built-in cargo compartments and similar features (which is what I wanted).

So basically: Yes, his is similar enough in general specifications to mine that I can say it'll be quite stable.

Just don't go out at night on a lake full of powerboaters, no matter how many running lights and light whips you stick on.

Also, these things are heavy and cumbersome, especially if they come with pedals. His would be almost 130 lbs. with the seat and pedals. That's why he has a wheel caddy. Mine is something like 86 lbs. without anything (including the seat) in it, and although I can toss half a pallet of 80 lb. bags of Quikrete up into a truck bed, moving the kayak is a struggle alone. It can be done, though. Thankfully I'm almost always with a buddy.

These are big and heavy, unlike "standard" kayaks.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Am I too old at 35 to learn and start sailing?

I've always had an interest in owning a sail boat, nothing crazy big max 30ft, but leaning more towards a 20ft summer pleasure boat, I live between Lake eerie, and Ontario so no shortage of space to sail.

I have a 3 year plan to save up and learn to sail between then, is that a possibility with only a little sailing experience? I know the basics of boating, and steering and such already.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502326
The boomers I used to sail with started after they retired. Just do it. I don't sail anymore but they all just went to marinas and snagged abandoned boats that other boomers didn't want to maintain anymore, so they only coughed up money for repairs, maintenance, fees, etc. All of their boats were very nice too. It just takes a bit of physical labor. Think of it like renovating a house.
I say you should just go to a marina and offer to help winterize some old guy's boat in exchange for him showing you the ropes. I'd bet money they'd take you up on it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502326
Get a membership somewhere with lessons for one summer, go 3-5 times a week, and then after that season you will always be a sailor. Trying to learn a over a weekend here or there across many years just isn't the same thing. Go when the weather is bad, sail when there's no wind, go when it's blowing so hard you might shit yourself. You need to experience all of that to get comfortable. Start with a small keelboat, controlling the boat and finding the wind. Sail as crew for a more experienced sailor and just focus on the jib. And then go to the smaller dinghies like the photo of the laser you posted. Then after that, the big boats will be very easy to control and you just need to learn the differences in the rigging.

Feel free to post tobaccos (no weed allowed), pipes, collections, pics of favorite combos for going /out/, pics of what you're doing with your pipe and any questions you might have.

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?
Get a corncob pipe and a pouch of either Captain Black or Half and Half tobacco, available at most drugstores.
What you'll need: pipe, tobacco, lighter or matches, pipe cleaners, and either a regular old nail or a pipe tool (combination tamper, scoop, and small pick).
All of these together should run you less than $25, still. God help you.

Having trouble keeping your pipe lit? Fill it with less tobacco and smoke it slower than you think you need to, lightly tamping as needed when the smoke starts thinning out.

last_replies.com:
gonna answer op's questions now.
might fuck around and haul more trash out of the swamp tomorrow.
>>2500866
its easy as fuck to sew webbing on, depending on what you're sewing it into. i would recommend having a cheap ass sewing machine but you can do it by hand. i think everyone into /out/ should have a sewing machine: with all the posts i see on this board about people wanting their gear to be eco friendly i sure don't see a lot of posts about repairing gear ;) good life skill to pick up.
if you're trying to sew it onto a normal backpack you could figure out how to do that with a youtube video and you could do it by hand without a sewing machine worst case pretty easily.
if you're trying to sew it into some 1000 denier military style pack you won't be able to do it yourself because you'll need a specialty sewing machine. your local luggage repair place will do it for like 10 bucks its a 5 second job for them.
>>2501019
i agree with this anon's post 100%
any cheap backpack made out of normal ass recreational hiker-thickness nylon will be fine for you. skip on the ultra lightweight stuff but you don't need a full on 1000 denier larpbag. i've rock climbed in the same shitty $30 rei backpack for almost 20 years. i'd just get something cheap on sale from a cheaper recreational brand like kelty/granite/rei/whatever if i were you. aus market is probably way different than the burger market so i hesitate to do specific recs. do you have rei there? can't go wrong with their flash/trail packs when on sale.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: and also if this is your first/primary backpack, i agree with you op 40-45 liters is the right size for most people for this. the one specific thing to look for is a pack that cinches down to smaller sizes well and carries well when it does. that way you can use this same backpack for your day-hikes and also your shorter backpacking trips, instead of needing two separate packs. not all backpacks 'scale down' well. picrel is an example of a good design.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: the other thing to look for when buying is the torso length of the pack. have a friend measure your torso for you. when anon and i say basically any pack will work for you, its with the caveat: has to fit well. if you're looking at either cheap or lightweight packs they're often not very adjustable so make sure to get it right. watch a few videos on youtube about how to fit a pack & bring a simulated load to fill it up with if you have the luxury of buying your backpack in person at a store.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2499275
I own two multitools, the left one is a Leatherman Wave clone by Bibury. Great quality for the price. Just recently took it with me on a multiday trip. The pliers are great, but not springloaded. There is a knife with a straight edge, as well as a serrated edge. Both come very sharp from the factory. The scissors are great too. The bit holder uses standard bits rather than Leathermans proprietary design, which is a plus too. I think Americans can get some other form of Wave clone at Walmart. The left tool is the Nextool Flagship. This was my first multitool and it has a great pair of scissors. Both the scissors and pliers are spring loaded. All the knives, sawes and files on both tools feature liner locks.

After testing the Bibury I'd definitely recommend it over the Nextool, since you get more features in a slightly smaller form factor. It is heavier though.

threads.com: Anyone live in Utah that could discuss usual weather conditions for the state? What part has more cold and what has more heat? Where’s the best place to go camping, hiking? Any good urban areas? Is Salt Lake City even worth visiting?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I lived in Las Vegas for a few decades and can speak about the southern half of Utah. The temperature in St. George is only a few degrees cooler than Vegas so highs of roughly 100 F in summer and lows of 30-35 F in winter. They have Bryce Canyon and Zion, both national parks and both worth visiting but crowded. There is also Lake Powell and the North Rim of the Grand Canyon although I've never been to either one.

By far my favorite place was the Dixie National Forest just east of Cedar City. While most of Southern Utah is semi-arid, most of the DNF is on a plain at roughly 10,000 feet and consequently more alpine. There are two larger lakes there, Panguitch and Navajo, both with a good deal of trout. Not much in the way of backpacking, the Dixie National Forest is ideal for camping because you can pull off anywhere and make your campsite.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I had a filson but didnt like it for out that much. I much prefer the anorak designs.
If you do go with Filson, prioritize the plaids. The non plaids are made overseas, 24 oz and pill much easier. For the longest time Filson denied their wool cloth had changed but now say their plaids (still made in us) are 26 oz and closer to old fabric.
If you are willing to spend that amount of money id look at weatherwool or stormy kromer for a much better value. You can also find filsons on ebay that are vintage.
But like I said, enjoyed anoraks much more out than most coats. They are cumbersome and when I want the durability I wear something else.
Lester river/empire canvas makes a great anorak but it is warm.
Theres a recent swedish one called miitgaard or something.
If you want value look at
Genuine australian bushwear bush shirt
Sukonka (russian)
Asbell (us)
Parsons anorak (us)
Varusteleka has an anorak
A canadian one called boreal mountain
Some of the nicer ($$$) ones you dont feel like wearing cause its like driving a tesla in the forest.

last_replies.com:
>>2501581
depending how far you have to travel you could put pic related in to encase it first. we did this with out pillar. the pillar itself was made from regular concrete mix in a 10" tube and we wheeled into the woods with a wooden yoke we made, but then to give it a solid base we dumped two bags of fast setting concrete into the hole before we sunk the pillar in. the quick setting stuff doesn't have to be mixed well, it's designed to be put in a hole dry and then you dump a small amount of water in (like a gallon or two) and stir it up a little. the water will soak any dry clumps before it sets, it's well designed. plus at the first rain it'll cure more completely anyway and then you'll have a solid 40 or 60 pound block of concrete as a vault

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2501113
Most people dying from hypothermia is not in the freezing winter, but casual unprepared hikers getting wet in the rain and it's only ~10c or so. They probably have a cotton t-shirt, cotton sweat shirt or hoodie, cotton pants/jeans, cotton socks, cotton underwear. They'll quickly cool down, start panic and possibly get lost or too far away from civilization.

In freezing temperatures cotton is alright because it doesn't really get wet.
There is tight woven cotton that is water resistant. Not sure how good it is.
Most outdoor cotton gear is mix with poly, 35-40% cotton, 60-65% poly. In my experience that will dry up fairly quickly.

In my experience, going fishing its a great way to start going /out/.
You dont need a lot of money to start doing it, you dont need to be very experienced since you can fish very close from a parking lot, and there Is a lot of tutorials in YouTube, also, you will learn what kind of clothes are good for being outside for long time, and what you need to bring (food, water, tools, etc)
Once you get confortable fishing during a whole day, you can start camping+fishing, to go one step further hiking+fishing+camping (at this point you can consider yourself a true /out/ist) then you can do camping+hiking only trips, and at this point you can start mountaineering. And It all starts with the humble zebco rod+reel combo.
Of course, I started fishing when I was 6.
